channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Xi and Putin Highlight Ties Between China and Russia
item.description: The two leaders met in Moscow as Xi Jinping made his first visit to Russia since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Xi called their two nations “good neighbors and reliable partners.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Anatoliy Zhdanov/Kommersant Photo, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: France Live Updates: Macron’s Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
item.description: The bill to increase the national retirement age to 64 from 62 now becomes law, but opponents vowed to continue their fight amid widespread fury against President Emmanuel Macron.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Children of the Iraq War Have Grown Up, but Some Wounds Don’t Heal
item.description: Twenty years after the U.S. invaded Iraq, a veteran Times correspondent and photographer asked Iraqis about growing up in wartime, and about their hopes now.
item.dc:creator: Joao Silva and Alissa J. Rubin

item.title: Meta Manager Was Hacked With Spyware and Wiretapped in Greece
item.description: Artemis Seaford, a dual U.S.-Greek national, was targeted with a cyberespionage tool while also under a wiretap by the Greek spy agency in a case that shows the spread of illicit snooping in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Artemis Seaford, shown in Washington this year, worked as a trust and safety manager for Meta from 2020 until late 2022.

item.title: Why China and Russia Are Closer Than Ever
item.description: This week’s meeting between the leaders of China and Russia marks another key moment in the deepening relationship between the two powers.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in February 2022. After that meeting, the leaders declared their commitment to a friendship with “no limits.”

item.title: Israel’s Leaders Advance Key Part of Judicial Overhaul but Delay Rest
item.description: The government vowed to press on with a plan to take more control over appointing judges. But other changes were postponed in a move that was presented as a concession.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A rally protesting the judicial overhaul blocked a highway in Tel Aviv on Saturday. The debate over the proposals has set off one of the deepest domestic crises in Israeli history.

item.title: Lead Exposure From U.S. Car Batteries Threatens Health of Mexican Workers
item.description: The removal of lead from car batteries, many from the United States, at recycling plants in northern Mexico has led to high levels of lead contamination, a new report found.
item.dc:creator: Steve Fisher and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: After tests showed high levels of lead in Azael Mateo González Ramírez’s body, his supervisor at a car battery recycling plant in northern Mexico insisted he keep working.

item.title: First Official Estimate of Somalia’s Drought Shows 43,000 Dead
item.description: At least half of the deaths were children under the age of 5, according to the report by health researchers, the United Nations and the Somali government.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up at a nutrition center run by a charitable group in Baidoa, Somalia, in November.

item.title: India Blocks Internet in Punjab as Security Forces Pursue Separatist
item.description: The rise of Amritpal Singh, a self-styled preacher, has raised fears of violence in Punjab, where thousands died in the 1980s during a Sikh insurgency.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Police officers outside the home of Amritpal Singh in Jallupur Khera, a village about 30 miles from Amritsar, India.

item.title: Biden Administration Authorizes $350 Million for Ukraine Military Aid
item.description: The latest infusion of aid is aimed at giving Ukraine much needed ammunition ahead of a planned spring offensive.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: U.S. Marines working on a High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems or HIMARS, in Capas, Philippines, in October.

item.title: Blinken Says Xi’s Russia Visit Amounts to ‘Diplomatic Cover’ for War Crimes
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state said the Chinese leader’s visit indicated that Beijing felt “no responsibility” to hold Russia accountable for atrocities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken addressing reporters in Washington on Monday.

item.title: Who’s Behind the Judicial Overhaul Now Dividing Israel? Two Americans.
item.description: Kohelet, the once-obscure think tank that conceived and now champions a revamped court system, is an American import.
item.dc:creator: David Segal and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of Israelis protested the government’s judicial overhaul plan on March 11.

item.title: European Officials Agree to Supply More Artillery Shells to Ukraine
item.description: European leaders adopted a plan to provide Ukraine with badly needed shells, while replenishing their own national stocks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian armed forces loading a howitzer in the Donetsk region in May.

item.title: What to Expect From France’s No-Confidence Vote
item.description: Lawmakers in the National Assembly will debate two motions to oust President Emmanuel Macron’s cabinet and defeat his plan to raise the national retirement age.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The French government has exposed itself to no-confidence motions that could bring down President Emmanuel Macron’s cabinet.

item.title: American Held Hostage in Africa Is Freed
item.description: Jeffery Woodke, an aid worker abducted in Niger by militants, was released after more than six years in captivity. A second hostage was also released: Olivier Dubois, a French journalist who disappeared in April 2021.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Jeffrey Woodke, an American, was kidnapped in Niger in October 2016.

item.title: 1948: Egypt Starts Power Project
item.description: Laying the foundation stone of a hydroelectric project that would have ambitious successors.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Australian State Moves to Ban Nazi Salute After Rally
item.description: After neo-Nazis appeared at a protest against transgender rights in Melbourne, a local politician was facing expulsion from her party for taking part in the demonstration.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Members of an Australian neo-Nazi group during a rally against transgender rights at Parliament House in Melbourne on Saturday.

item.title: Who Are Russia’s Friends Amid the War in Ukraine?
item.description: India and South Africa are among the nations that have not criticized Russia for invading Ukraine. Some others have supplied military aid.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, and President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus in Minsk, Belarus, in December.

item.title: Earth to Hit Critical Global Warming Threshold by Early 2030s
item.description: A new U.N. report says it is still possible to hold global warming to relatively safe levels, but doing so will require global cooperation, billions of dollars and big changes.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Hoesung Lee, chair of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, speaking at the global climate talks on Nov. 6 in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt.

item.title: What Could Happen If Trump Is Indicted This Week
item.description: If Trump is indicted, this week will be unlike any other in American politics.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Donald Trump.

item.title: A WWII Pilot Saved His Crew. It Took 80 Years to Identify His Remains.
item.description: Lt. William B. Montgomery flew a B-24 Liberator toward the British coast after it was hit in June 1944. Historians credit him for saving the lives of seven crew members.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: First Lt. William B. Montgomery, front row, second from right, with other members of the U.S. Army Air Forces. He piloted a B-24 Liberator that was struck by antiaircraft fire while on a mission to bomb an airfield near the German-occupied Paris.

item.title: Some Details on the Agenda for Xi Jinping’s Visit to Russia
item.description: The Chinese leader is expected to talk to Vladimir V. Putin about Ukraine and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Will Trump be arrested this week?
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump speaking last week in Iowa.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Putin and Xi to Meet in Moscow
item.description: Also, Donald Trump says his arrest is imminent and UBS agrees to buy Credit Suisse.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: An image taken from video footage released on Sunday by Russian TV shows President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Lab Leak or Not? How Politics Shaped the Battle Over Covid’s Origin
item.description: A lab leak was once dismissed by many as a conspiracy theory. But the idea is gaining traction, even as evidence builds that the virus emerged from a market.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: The Wuhan Institute of Virology is known for its advanced research on bat coronaviruses.

item.title: A ‘New Cold War’ Looms in Africa as U.S. Pushes Against Russian Gains
item.description: The U.S. is reprising its playbook in Ukraine, where it has used classified information to expose plans by Russia. Next target: Chad.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: An independence celebration in Ndjamena, Chad, in 2021, the year the country’s autocratic leader of three decades was killed in battle with rebels.

item.title: Amid Violence, Israeli and Palestinian Officials Meet to Promote Calm
item.description: Fearing that an already-bloody year could worsen during Ramadan, Palestinians and Israelis met for the second time in a month.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian men fixing cars last week in an area that was set on fire by Jewish settlers in the Palestinian town of Huwara, south of the West Bank city of Nablus.

item.title: Assad’s 2nd Diplomatic Trip in Days Speeds Easing of Isolation
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, welcomed in the Emirati capital with a 21-gun salute, is gradually re-emerging after the global shunning that followed his violent crushing of his country’s 2011 uprising.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Abdulla Al Neyadi/UAE Presidential Court, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, left, with Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed, the ruler of the United Arab Emirates, in Abu Dhabi on Sunday.

item.title: Chaos Up Close
item.description: A look at the collateral damage of homelessness.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Joe Faillace unlocking the gate on a fence around the sandwich shop that he and his wife have run for four decades.

item.title: To Combat Food Shortages, North Korea Deploys the Military
item.description: Kim Jong-un, the country’s leader, has called for soldiers to be “a driving force” in increasing food production, a reflection of the North’s economic and geopolitical challenges.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In a photograph provided by North Korean state media, North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, is said to visit a greenhouse farm in the eastern part of the country.

item.title: China as Peacemaker in the Ukraine War? The U.S. and Europe Are Skeptical.
item.description: Chinese officials say Xi Jinping’s upcoming trip to Moscow is a peace mission. But U.S. and European officials say he aims to bolster Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing last year. Mr. Xi plans to visit the Russian president this week.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Charts Post-Brexit Role With Pivot From ‘Global Britain’
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has dropped Boris Johnson’s bombastic approach to foreign policy, reflecting the new British leader’s personal style and the country’s changed global status.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in London. Analysts and diplomats say he has begun to chart a realistic role for Britain in the global arena for the first time since Brexit.

item.title: In U.S.-Led Iraq War, Iran Was the Big Winner
item.description: In the 20 years since the United States invaded Iraq, Iran has built up loyal militias inside Iraq, gained deep political influence in the country and reaped economic benefits. For Washington, these were unintended consequences.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pilgrims at the Imam Ali shrine in Najaf, an Iraqi Shiite holy city, during a pilgrimage in September.

item.title: Russia Is Closing In on Bakhmut, but Casualties Are High
item.description: Sending unarmed “diggers” into the front lines and near certain death, Russian troops are making slow but inexorable progress.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s Third Assault Brigade have spent the past three months fighting waves of Russian soldiers around the eastern city of Bakhmut.

item.title: Putin Visits Mariupol After ICC Arrest Warrant
item.description: The trip was the Russian leader’s first to territory his forces captured since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and came shortly after an international court issued a warrant for his arrest for war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: An image taken from video footage released on Sunday by Russian TV shows President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: The Secret Behind Japan’s Delicious Strawberries: Kerosene
item.description: The growing season has become completely reversed thanks to kerosene-burning greenhouses and the big prices paid for the earliest, best berries.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Signals It Will Take More Ukrainian Children, a Crime in Progress
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin highlights a practice that the Kremlin has not concealed and says will continue.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Emma Bubola
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a smashed frame late last year outside a police prison in Kherson that Russian forces used to hold and torture Ukrainian prisoners.

item.title: Cuba Will Play World Baseball Classic Game in Miami
item.description: Protests are likely, but some cheers are also expected as the team plays a World Baseball Classic semifinal game in the city with the highest Cuban population in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Cuba’s national baseball team has struggled in recent years but qualified for the semifinals of the World Baseball Classic by beating Australia in a quarterfinal game played in Japan on Wednesday.

item.title: Imran Khan Makes Court Appearance and Chaos Breaks Out
item.description: Supporters of the former prime minister of Pakistan have repeatedly clashed this week with the security forces, keeping the country on edge. “Show you can fight,” he told supporters.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan in Lahore on Friday, after a court prohibited the police from arresting Mr. Khan in several cases filed against him.

item.title: Claims of Chinese Election Meddling Put Trudeau on Defensive
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is battling critics and leaked intelligence reports that opponents say show he ignored warnings of Chinese interference in past elections.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Claims of Chinese interference on Canada’s 2019 and 2021 elections, including Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s party’s victory, have raised criticism from the country’s opposition parties.

item.title: Why Canada’s Banks Remain ‘Stable and Resilient’
item.description: The country’s financial stability, and the high profitability of its banks at a time when those in the U.S. are in turmoil, comes from strong regulations.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Six large banks dominate Canada’s market.

item.title: Spring Returns
item.description: Like everything else, spring has its adherents and detractors.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Putin Visits Occupied Crimea, a Day After War-Crimes Warrant
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia marked the anniversary of his illegal seizure of the Ukrainian peninsula, signaling defiance to the world and business as usual to his own people.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, visited the port city of Sevastopol in Crimea on Saturday, as seen in a photo provided by the Russian government.

item.title: Macron Faces an Angry France Alone
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron saw his decision to push through a change in the retirement age as necessary, but the price may be high.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen

item.title: In Stoic Ukraine, Stony Faces Are Starting to Crack and to Cry
item.description: Although Ukrainians excel at putting up a brave front, a tremendous amount of suffering is being kept bottled up and sometimes bursts out.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning a fallen soldier in Lviv, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: In Photos: The Iraq War
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 20 Years After U.S. Invasion, Iraq Is a Freer Place, but Not a Hopeful One
item.description: Conversations with dozens of Iraqis offer a portrait of a nation that is rich in oil, hobbled by corruption and unable to guarantee its citizens’ safety.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Kamil Jassim Mohammed, the custodian of the martyrs’ cemetery in Falluja, Iraq. It is hard to find anyone in Iraq who has not lost someone.

item.title: 20 Years On, a Question Lingers About Iraq: Why Did the U.S. Invade?
item.description: Two decades after the Bush administration said it wanted to disarm weapons of mass destruction and free Iraqis, the debates rage on about who knew what when, and which motive mattered most.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher

item.title: WHO Accuses China of Withholding Data on Covid’s Origins
item.description: Genetic research from China suggests to some experts that the coronavirus may have sprung from a seafood market in Wuhan. Now the data are missing from a scientific database.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Because questions remain about the samples and why the evidence disappeared, some scientists reacted cautiously, saying that it was difficult to assess the research without seeing a complete report.

item.title: China’s Xi to Visit Putin Under Shadow of War-Crimes Warrant
item.description: Global divisions over Russia’s actions in Ukraine widened as China said Xi Jinping would go to Russia to help make peace, in a move widely seen as a stark sign of support for President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with President Xi Jinping of China via video conference at the Kremlin in December.

item.title: Arrest Warrant From ICC Pierces Putin’s Aura of Impunity
item.description: A highly symbolic move by the International Criminal Court, which accused President Vladimir V. Putin of war crimes, carries moral weight.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: What to Know About the ICC’s Arrest Warrant for Putin
item.description: The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin and a Russian official for war crimes. Here’s a look at the warrant and what it could mean for Russia’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons, Charlie Savage and Anushka Patil
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A smashed portrait of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia seen last year outside a police prison in Kherson City, Ukraine, where occupying Russian forces held Ukrainian prisoners.

item.title: When Judges Decide on Abortion
item.description: Cases in Poland and Texas bring legal vulnerabilities into sharp relief.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Anna Liminowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A court in Poland on Tuesday found Justyna Wydrzynska, a women’s rights activist, guilty of aiding an abortion by providing pills, the first conviction of its type in the country and in Europe.

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Finally Endorses Finland’s NATO Bid, but Not Sweden’s
item.description: With a difficult election coming in May, the Turkish president keeps insisting that Sweden is harboring alleged Kurdish terrorists and other dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto of Finland and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara, Turkey, on Friday.
